Notes: Jim writes: Hist. (mainly 1950s). A cluster of terms associated with the group housing scheme introduced in 1953 whereby numbers of low-cost houses in a subdivision were built by a private builder for sale - group house, group housing, group builder. Often the State developed the subdivision and provided services, selling the developed block to a private builder. The scheme offered home ownership as an alternative to State rental houses and was very popular... These terms are not recorded in DNZE. Note - 1. Of possible linguistic interest is the official use in this context of the term block in the sense of an area subdivided for group (or State) housing and site (not lot) in the sense of an individual section in such a block. There is no trace in the literature I have seen of the English term housing estate. 2. Group houses are associated in my recollection with parades of homes, at which the variety of homes in a group housing block were open for inspection by prospective buyers. This term seems to extend slightly the ordinary meanings of parade and is possibly a distinctive NZE compound.
